definitions.definition: a faculty by which the body perceives an external stimulus; one of the faculties of sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch.
examples: the bear has a keen sense of smell that enables it to hunt at dusk

definitions.definition: a feeling that something is the case.
examples: she had the sense of being a political outsider

definitions.definition: an awareness or feeling that one is in a specified state.
examples: you can improve your general health and sense of well-being

definitions.definition: a keen intuitive awareness of or sensitivity to the presence or importance of something.
examples: she had a fine sense of comic timing

definitions.definition: a sane and realistic attitude to situations and problems.
examples: he earned respect by the good sense he showed at meetings
synonyms: (street) smarts "she had the sense to press the panic button"

examples: I can't see the sense in leaving all the work to you
synonyms: benefit "I can't see the sense in this"

definitions.definition: a way in which an expression or a situation can be interpreted; a meaning.
examples: it is not clear which sense of the word “characters” is intended in this passage

definitions.definition: a property, e.g., direction of motion, distinguishing a pair of objects, quantities, effects, etc., that differ only in that each is the reverse of the other.
relating to or denoting a coding sequence of nucleotides, complementary to an antisense sequence.
perceive by a sense or senses.
examples: with the first frost, they could sense a change in the days
synonyms: intuit; informalcatch on to "she sensed their hostility"

examples: she could sense her father's anger rising

definitions.definition: be aware that something is the case without being able to define exactly how one knows.
examples: he could sense that he wasn't liked

definitions.definition: (of a machine or similar device) detect.
examples: an optical fiber senses a current flowing in a conductor
